project_metadata.paper_title: Is archaeology a science? Insights and imperatives from 10,000 articles and a year of reproducibility reviews
project_metadata.research_context: Bibliometric analysis of approximately 10,000 articles from 20 archaeology journals (1975-2025) to assess archaeology's position on the hard-soft science spectrum, combined with systematic analysis of 12 months of computational reproducibility reviews (47 reviews of 25 manuscripts) at the Journal of Archaeological Science.

persistent_identifiers.notes: Author ORCID not provided in paper. Zenodo deposit contains all R code and data for reproducing figures, tables, and statistical tests.

funding.notes: No funding statement included in paper. Part of special issue honouring Robin Torrence (50th anniversary of JAS).

data_availability.statement_text: The data that support the findings of this study are openly available in Zenodo at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14897252.

machine_actionability.rationale: Zenodo provides DOI resolution, structured DataCite metadata, and programmatic access via API. Data files are in structured formats suitable for reuse.

code_availability.statement_text: The entire R code (R Core Team, 2024) used for all the analysis and visualizations contained in this paper is at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14897252 to enable re-use of materials and improve reproducibility and transparency.
code_availability.documentation_level: Good - README expected in compendium; paper explicitly enables independent reproduction of figures, tables, and statistical tests

environment_specification.details: Paper mentions R Core Team (2024) and various R packages (renv, targets, Quarto mentioned as best practices). Specific environment specification (renv.lock) likely present in compendium.

machine_actionability.rationale: Zenodo provides DOI resolution and structured metadata. R code in standard format. Paper explicitly states all figures, tables, and statistical test results can be independently reproduced.

author_contributions.notes: Single-author paper; no CReDIT statement required.

conflicts_of_interest.declaration_text: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

ethics_approval.notes: Meta-analysis of published literature and journal review data; no human subjects research requiring ethics approval.

permits_and_authorisations.notes: Meta-analysis study; no fieldwork permits required.

preregistration.notes: Exploratory bibliometric analysis; preregistration not standard for this research type.

materials_list.description: Research compendium with R code, data, and reproducible analysis

references_completeness.notes: Comprehensive reference list including primary sources for reproducibility studies across multiple disciplines, methodological guidance, and philosophical/sociological literature on science.

findable.rationale: Data in Zenodo with DOI (F1), DataCite metadata (F2), DOI in metadata (F3), indexed in DataCite/Google Dataset Search (F4).

accessible.rationale: HTTPS via DOI resolver (A1), no authentication required (A1.1), open access with no restrictions (A1.2), Zenodo metadata persistence guaranteed (A2).

interoperable.rationale: Structured data formats expected (CSV, R data frames) (I1), no explicit controlled vocabulary usage documented (I2), DOI links to paper and related resources (I3).

reusable.rationale: Detailed documentation enabling reproduction (R1), explicit CC-0 licence (R1.1), R code documents processing pipeline (R1.2), follows Marwick et al. (2018) compendium standards (R1.3).

data_fairness.rationale: Bibliometric data and reproducibility review data shared via Zenodo with DOI, explicit licences, and comprehensive documentation. Exemplary data sharing practices.

findable.rationale: Code in Zenodo with DOI (F1), DataCite metadata (F2), DOI in metadata (F3), indexed (F4).

accessible.rationale: HTTPS via DOI (A1), open access (A1.1), no restrictions (A1.2), Zenodo persistence (A2).

interoperable.rationale: R is standard open-source language (I1), no software ontology usage (I2), paper references code via DOI (I3).

reusable.rationale: Compendium structure enables reuse (R1), MIT licence explicit (R1.1), computational workflow documented (R1.2), follows research compendium standards (R1.3).

code_fairness.rationale: Complete R code archived in Zenodo with DOI, MIT licence, and documentation enabling independent reproduction of all results.

fair_assessment.fair_profile: Highly FAIR (computational research with exemplary practices for both data and code)
fair_assessment.contextual_notes: Exemplary FAIR practices from author who is JAS Associate Editor for Reproducibility. Demonstrates best practices advocated in paper: research compendium with Zenodo DOI, explicit licences (MIT/CC-0/CC-BY), R code enabling independent reproduction. One of few papers in test corpus achieving near-maximum FAIR scores for both data and code dimensions.

extraction_metadata.notes: Pass 0 (metadata) and Pass 6 (infrastructure) completed in Session A. Paper is meta-analysis combining bibliometric study and reproducibility review analysis. Exemplary reproducibility infrastructure consistent with author's role as JAS reproducibility editor.

evidence.evidence_text: Bibliometric sample of nearly 10,000 articles analysed
evidence.verbatim_quote: Analyzing nearly 10,000 articles, I identify trends in authorship, citation practices, and related metrics that position archaeology between the natural and social sciences.

evidence.evidence_text: 47 reproducibility reviews of 25 manuscripts conducted
evidence.verbatim_quote: At the time of writing (January 2025) we have completed 47 reproducibility reviews of 25 manuscripts submitted to JAS (most papers required multiple reviews).

evidence.evidence_text: Persistent challenges identified: missing data, unspecified dependencies, inadequate documentation
evidence.verbatim_quote: A survey of reproducibility reviews for the Journal of Archaeological Science reveals persistent challenges, including missing data, unspecified dependencies, and inadequate documentation.

evidence.evidence_text: Bibliometric sample construction: 9,697 papers from 20 journals, filtered from initial 28,871 articles in Web of Science
evidence.verbatim_quote: I analysed 9697 papers published during 1975–2025. This sample was collected from Clarivate's Web of Science database by first selecting the Web of Science category 'Archaeology' and the Document type 'article' (n = 28,871). Finally, I excluded journals with less than 100 articles in the database, resulting in 20 journals.

consolidation_metadata.granularity_available: Individual filtering steps: initial 28,871 → top 25 by h-index → exclude <100 articles → 20 journals, 9,697 papers
consolidation_metadata.rationale: All three items support only C011 and describe sequential steps in sample construction. Would assess together as methodology completeness.

evidence.evidence_text: Archaeology positioned between social sciences and physics on author count
evidence.verbatim_quote: The most striking indicator of archaeology as a hard science is the number of authors, where it is between the social sciences and physics.

evidence.evidence_text: Archaeology similar to social sciences in relative title length
evidence.verbatim_quote: Archaeology is a close fit with the social sciences in relative title length.

evidence.evidence_text: Archaeology between social sciences and humanities in reference metrics
evidence.verbatim_quote: It is between the social sciences and humanities in recency of references and diversity of references.

evidence.evidence_text: Archaeology similar to humanities in article length
evidence.verbatim_quote: The clearest indicator of archaeology as a soft science is article length where it is similar to the humanities.

evidence.evidence_text: Author count temporal trend shows highest r-squared
evidence.verbatim_quote: The most striking change over time is in the increase in the number of authors, which has the highest r-squared value of these metrics.

evidence.evidence_text: Three metrics show archaeology becoming softer over time
evidence.verbatim_quote: On the other hand, three metrics indicate that archaeology has become softer (diversity of references, article length and recently of references).

evidence.evidence_text: R-squared values are very low for temporal trends
evidence.verbatim_quote: Similarly the r-squared values are very low, demonstrating that much of the variability in these metrics is independent of time.

evidence.evidence_text: Reference diversity increased after 2010
evidence.verbatim_quote: One interesting detail evident in Fig. 2 is the increase in the range of diversity of references after about 2010.

evidence.evidence_text: Kendall's coefficient of concordance Wt = 0.64 for journal ranking
evidence.verbatim_quote: Overall agreement between these bibliometric variables in ranking these journals on a hard-soft spectrum is moderate to strong, with a Kendall's coefficient of concordance (Wt) value of 0.64 (in a 0–1 range, where 1 is perfect agreement) and a p-value of 2.67 × 10−06.

evidence.evidence_text: JAS ranked among top five archaeology journals for hardness
evidence.verbatim_quote: Panel F of Fig. 3 shows an overall consensus ranking of all journals in the sample. In this consensus ranking the Journal of Archaeological Science among the top five archaeology journals for hardness.

evidence.evidence_text: Journal of Cultural Heritage consistently ranks hard across all variables
evidence.verbatim_quote: The Journal of Cultural Heritage is the only journal that consistently ranks as hard across all variables, occurring in the top five journals for all five metrics.

evidence.evidence_text: Journal of Archaeological Research consistently ranks as soft
evidence.verbatim_quote: The Journal of Archaeological Research is notable for consistently ranking as soft; it was the softest journal for four of our five bibliometric variables.

evidence.evidence_text: PCA results: PC1 captures 71% of variance, driven by title length, pages, diversity; PC2 influenced by author count and reference recency
evidence.verbatim_quote: The PCA results in Fig. 4 show that PC1 captures most of the variance in the metrics (71 %) and is a reasonable proxy for the hard-soft spectrum. The variables that contribute to variation in PC1 are title length, number of pages, and the diversity of references. Variation in PC2 is influenced by the number of authors and recency of references.

consolidation_metadata.granularity_available: PC1: 71% variance, variables = title length, pages, diversity of references. PC2: author count, recency of references.
consolidation_metadata.rationale: All three items support only C026 and describe components of the same PCA analysis. Would assess together as single statistical result.

evidence.evidence_text: NSF definition of reproducibility
evidence.verbatim_quote: This is reproducibility, which, according to a report for the US National Science Foundation (Cacioppo et al., 2015), "refers to the ability of a researcher to duplicate the results of a prior study using the same materials as were used by the original investigator."

evidence.evidence_text: Psychology replication: 36% vs 96% original
evidence.verbatim_quote: Empirical replications of 100 studies published in three psychology journals found that 36 % of replications had statistically significant results, compared to 96 % of the original studies (Open Science Collaboration, 2015).

evidence.evidence_text: Social science replication: 61-62% success
evidence.verbatim_quote: Similar empirical replications of large numbers of social science studies and experimental economics studies successfully replicated 61 % and 62 % of their target studies respectively (Camerer et al., 2016, 2018).

evidence.evidence_text: Science journal computational reproducibility: 26%
evidence.verbatim_quote: An attempt at reproducing the computational results of 204 papers in Science resulted in success in reproducing the findings for 26 % (Stodden et al., 2018).

evidence.evidence_text: Geoscience reproducibility: 2 of 41 papers on first attempt
evidence.verbatim_quote: The computational results of two out of 41 geoscience papers could be fully reproduced on the first attempt (Konkol et al., 2019).

evidence.evidence_text: Biomedical notebooks: 4% could run without errors
evidence.verbatim_quote: In the biomedical field, code in 1203 out of 27,271 (4 %) notebooks associated with 3467 publications could be run without errors (Samuel and Mietchen, 2024).

evidence.evidence_text: Statistics reproducibility: 15% of 93 papers
evidence.verbatim_quote: Statisticians could reproduce 15 % of 93 papers (Xiong and Cribben, 2023).

evidence.evidence_text: Economics reproducibility rates: 14-44%
evidence.verbatim_quote: Economists have been especially active in researching computational reproducibility, with studies indicating successful reproduction of results using code and data provided by authors for 30 % of 67 papers (Chang and Li, 2015), 14 % of 203 papers (Gertler et al., 2018), 44 % of 152 papers (Herbert et al., 2021), 30 % of 419 articles (Fišar et al., 2024), and 28 % of 168 papers (Pérignon et al., 2024).

evidence.evidence_text: Author began AER role January 2024
evidence.verbatim_quote: In January 2024 I accepted the position of 'Associate Editor for Reproducibility' (AER) for JAS and conducted reproducibility reviews of submissions that mentioned programming languages such as R or Python in the methods sections

evidence.evidence_text: 11 papers published in JAS to date from review process
evidence.verbatim_quote: Of these, 11 have been published in JAS to date.

evidence.evidence_text: 7 of 11 papers fully passed reproducibility review (63%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Seven of these eleven papers fully passed the reproducibility review, resulting in a success rate, by one measure, of 63 %.

evidence.evidence_text: 4 of 7 papers reproduced on first attempt
evidence.verbatim_quote: Four of the seven papers could be fully reproduced on my first attempt, the others required additional input from the authors.

evidence.evidence_text: 28% success rate (7 of 25 reviewed)
evidence.verbatim_quote: For comparison with reproducibility studies in other fields reported above, the seven fully reproducible papers should be divided by the 25 reviewed for reproducibility, resulting in a 28 % success rate.

evidence.evidence_text: 7% success rate when including all 97 eligible articles
evidence.verbatim_quote: Expanding the denominator to include the total number of research articles published in JAS from May 2024 (when the first article to pass the reproducibility review, Herskind and Riede (2024), was published) to January 2025 (n = 97) offers another perspective. These 97 articles that could have been eligible for reproducibility review had the authors used an open source programming language... Under this broader scope, the success rate is 7 %

evidence.evidence_text: Same 7% rate found in ecology journals study
evidence.verbatim_quote: a result also found in a study of 497 papers in 9 ecology journals (Kellner et al., 2025).

evidence.evidence_text: R most common software, followed by Python
evidence.verbatim_quote: The most commonly used software is R, followed by Python.

evidence.evidence_text: GMM, network stats, and AI/ML well-represented in sample
evidence.verbatim_quote: Several distinct types of analyses are well-represented in this sample, especially geometric morphometry, network statistics, and analyses using artificial intelligence or machine learning algorithms (this includes deep learning and neural networks).

evidence.evidence_text: Zenodo most popular repository for code/data
evidence.verbatim_quote: Most authors are sharing their code and data files via Zenodo, a non-profit generic research data repository hosted by CERN that accepts any file format and freely assigns all publicly available uploads a DOI to make the files easily and uniquely citable (Peters et al., 2017).

evidence.evidence_text: Incomplete compendium most common issue
evidence.verbatim_quote: The most common issue was an incomplete compendium. This ranges from missing data files down to missing lines of code.

evidence.evidence_text: Unspecified dependencies another common issue
evidence.verbatim_quote: Unspecified or under-specified dependencies is another common issue that prevents code from running.

evidence.evidence_text: Data licensing caused two cases of unavailability
evidence.verbatim_quote: In most cases this can be attributed to accidental carelessness, with the exception of two cases where data was unavailable due to licensing restrictions.

evidence.evidence_text: Path specification and function errors also caused failures
evidence.verbatim_quote: Other reasons why papers failed the reproducibility review is that the paths to data files were incorrectly specified (likely a result of the author reorganising their compendium after completing their analysis, or omitting data files from the materials submitted for review), and errors returned by functions, which have diverse causes.

evidence.evidence_text: Dependency issues strongly associated with Python
evidence.verbatim_quote: In our sample, issues relating to dependencies are strongly associated with the use of Python.

evidence.evidence_text: Python uses more package managers and deeper dependency chains
evidence.verbatim_quote: One possible reason for this is that relative to R, Python uses more package managers, more environments, and deeper dependency chains with more complex inter-dependencies that change more rapidly (Decan et al., 2016, 2019; Korkmaz et al., 2020).

evidence.evidence_text: Larger, more established R community in archaeology
evidence.verbatim_quote: Another reason may be that there is a bigger and more established community of R users in archaeology (Batist and Roe, 2024; Schmidt and Marwick, 2020) that highly values code that is easy for others to reuse and has evolved practices to effectively communicate dependencies

evidence.evidence_text: Over 90% of analyses not highly time-consuming
evidence.verbatim_quote: Finally, for analyses that are not highly time-consuming (which was over 90 % of the sample), authors should re-run their code more than once, and ideally not on the same computer

evidence.evidence_text: Vernon and Ortman (2024) and Ragno (2024) used Quarto for entire manuscripts
evidence.verbatim_quote: Quarto was a popular tool among the JAS papers in the reproducibility review sample, for example, Vernon and Ortman (2024) and Ragno (2024) wrote their entire manuscripts using Quarto.

evidence.evidence_text: Four archaeology journals added AERs in 2024
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2024, three archaeology journals, in addition to JAS, added AERs to their editorial communities: Advances in Archaeological Practice (Marwick, 2024, one paper reviewed), Journal of Field Archaeology (Farahani, 2024, two papers reviewed), and American Antiquity (Martin, 2024, no papers reviewed at the time of writing).

evidence.evidence_text: Substantial amount of archaeological research is qualitative
evidence.verbatim_quote: a very substantial amount of archaeological research is qualitative, with few or no numerical data involved in making knowledge claims about the human past.

evidence.evidence_text: Qualitative research examples: presence/absence, shape, colour, chaîne opératoire
evidence.verbatim_quote: For example, many archaeological questions can be answered by the simple presence or absence of artefacts or features, or qualitative comparisons of basic artefact characteristics such as shape, colour, surface treatments, and raw material. Chaîne opératoire analyses by ceramic and lithic specialists is an especially productive area of archaeological research that often relies on comparison of narratives of manufacturing processes.

evidence.evidence_text: Gulliver's Travels metaphor for reproducibility frustration
evidence.verbatim_quote: In the classic satirical novel Gulliver's Travels (1726) by Irish writer Jonathon Swift Gulliver visits the fictional Grand Academy of Lagado in Balnibarbi, a caricature of the Royal Society of London, and meets several researchers working on wildly impractical projects, including one attempting to extracting sunbeams out of cucumbers.

claims.claim_text: Archaeology is positioned between natural and social sciences on hard-soft spectrum based on bibliometric analysis
claims.verbatim_quote: Analyzing nearly 10,000 articles, I identify trends in authorship, citation practices, and related metrics that position archaeology between the natural and social sciences.

claims.claim_text: Reproducibility is a factor in hardness/softness of fields because of its importance in establishing consensus
claims.verbatim_quote: Reproducibility is a factor in the hardness/softness of a field because of its importance in establishing consensus.

claims.claim_text: Urgent need for cultural and technical shifts to establish reproducibility as cornerstone of archaeological science
claims.verbatim_quote: This study underscores the urgent need for cultural and technical shifts to establish reproducibility as a cornerstone of rigorous, accountable, and impactful archaeological science.

claims.claim_text: Reproducibility necessary for archaeological science to behave like a science
claims.verbatim_quote: reproducibility was an issue important to the reputation and sustainability of the discipline, and necessary for archaeological science to behave like a science.

claims.claim_text: Previous debates on archaeology's status lacked macroscopic observation of actual practice
claims.verbatim_quote: What has been missing from these debates is a macroscopic observation of what the majority of archaeologists are actually doing, and an empirical comparison to a broad spectrum of relatively harder and softer disciplines.

claims.claim_text: Historical debates based mostly on personal observations and cherry-picked case studies
claims.verbatim_quote: these debates, and the many more similar ones summarised by Martinón-Torres and Killick (2013), have become a genre in archaeological writing that can be characterized as mostly based on personal observations, microscopic dissections of a handful of cherry-picked case studies of good or bad practice, and discussion of various philosophers and sociologists.

claims.claim_text: Hard-soft distinction defined by amount of consensus and speed of consensus formation
claims.verbatim_quote: In sum, the hard-soft status is defined by the amount of consensus in a field, and the speed at which consensus is reached on new knowledge (Fanelli and Glänzel, 2013).

claims.claim_text: Analysing hard-soft characteristics useful for understanding diversity of academic inquiry
claims.verbatim_quote: On the other hand, analyzing the characteristics that lead to the hard-soft distinction can be useful for understanding the diversity of academic inquiry, such as how different fields approach knowledge and differences in what counts as evidence and modes of argument

claims.claim_text: Bibliometric approach provides objective quantification of archaeological practice across hard-soft scale
claims.verbatim_quote: To objectively quantify the diversity of modern archaeological practice across a scale of relative hardness or softness, as an evaluation of its status as a science, and the place of this journal in context of other archaeology journals, I take a bibliometric approach.

claims.claim_text: Bibliometric variables are useful because they signify consensus in research community
claims.verbatim_quote: These parameters are useful because of how they signify consensus in a research community.

claims.claim_text: Larger author numbers reflect collaboration with specialised roles; harder fields have larger collaborator groups
claims.verbatim_quote: A larger number of authors on a paper reflects collaboration of people working together on a common goal. Collaborators have specialised roles, each of whom has the ability to study a part of the problem with high accuracy and detail, with harder fields having larger groups of collaborators (Zuckerman and Merton, 1972).

claims.claim_text: Article length inversely correlated with field hardness; softer fields need more justification
claims.verbatim_quote: Article length has an inverse correlation with field hardness. In low-consensus, or softer, fields, papers must be longer to present justification, nuance and contextualization of results.

claims.claim_text: Recency of references (Price index) measures how rapidly fields assimilate new results
claims.verbatim_quote: The age of works cited has long been used as a measure of a field's hardness (Börner, 2010; Moed et al., 1998), based on the assumption that harder fields assimilate new results more rapidly that softer fields (Price, 1970).

claims.claim_text: Higher diversity of references indicates softer fields with less core knowledge
claims.verbatim_quote: Conversely, softer fields have less knowledge taken for granted, a smaller core of facts that do not need citing, and thus a higher diversity of citations.

claims.claim_text: Archaeology does not sit squarely at either end of hard-soft spectrum
claims.verbatim_quote: Overall, archaeology does not sit squarely at either end of the hard-soft spectrum. It is generally not a harder science than the social sciences, with the exception of collaborator group sizes.

claims.claim_text: Archaeology generally not harder than social sciences except for collaborator group sizes
claims.verbatim_quote: It is generally not a harder science than the social sciences, with the exception of collaborator group sizes.

claims.claim_text: By two measures archaeology has become increasingly harder over time (authors, title length)
claims.verbatim_quote: By two measures, the number of authors and relative title length, archaeology has become increasingly harder over time.

claims.claim_text: Three metrics indicate archaeology has become softer over time
claims.verbatim_quote: On the other hand, three metrics indicate that archaeology has become softer (diversity of references, article length and recently of references).

claims.claim_text: Temporal trends in hardness metrics are very weak with low slopes indicating slow change
claims.verbatim_quote: Although all the relationships are statistically significant, generally these temporal trends are very weak with low slope values, indicating very slow change over time.

claims.claim_text: R-squared values demonstrate much variability in metrics independent of time
claims.verbatim_quote: Similarly the r-squared values are very low, demonstrating that much of the variability in these metrics is independent of time.

claims.claim_text: Moderate to strong agreement between bibliometric variables in ranking journals on hard-soft spectrum
claims.verbatim_quote: Overall agreement between these bibliometric variables in ranking these journals on a hard-soft spectrum is moderate to strong, with a Kendall's coefficient of concordance (Wt) value of 0.64

claims.claim_text: Journal of Cultural Heritage is outlier - publishes papers not engaging with anthropological topics
claims.verbatim_quote: Notably, papers in this journal typically do not engage in questions or debates about past human behavior or culture. The absence of these questions in research published in this journal makes it an outlier here, since these questions are central to a common definition of archaeology as 'cultural anthropology of the past'

claims.claim_text: Journal of Archaeological Research soft ranking predictable for review journal type
claims.verbatim_quote: This is a predicable result for a review journal, which is a distinct type of journal dedicated to summarising, analyzing, and synthesizing existing research in a particular field.

claims.claim_text: PCA reveals distinct communities of practice very close on hard-soft spectrum with minor communication style differences
claims.verbatim_quote: Among archaeology journals, we see distinct communities of practice reflected in the PCA results that are very close together on the hard-soft spectrum, but have minor differences in their communication styles, perhaps due to cultural differences in writing traditions inherited from parent disciplines such as geology and biology

claims.claim_text: JAS sits midway between specialised and generalist communities of practice
claims.verbatim_quote: The Journal of Archaeological Science sits about midway between these two groups, reflecting its relevance to both specialised and generalist communities of practice in archaeology.

claims.claim_text: Reference diversity increase after 2010 may be due to digital publishing changes
claims.verbatim_quote: This may be due to some broader changes in academic publishing around this time, such as moves to digital-first continuous publishing, new journals appearing (e.g. Archaeological and Anthropological Sciences in 2009 and Journal of Island & Coastal Archaeology in 2010), and non-archaeology journals becoming more relevant to archaeologists.

claims.claim_text: Reproducibility is minimum necessary condition for findings to be believable and informative
claims.verbatim_quote: Reproducibility is a minimum necessary condition for a finding to be believable and informative.

claims.claim_text: Scientific reproducibility is a factor contributing to hardness of a field
claims.verbatim_quote: Scientific reproducibility is a factor contributing to the hardness of a field. Specifically, reproducibility is linked to concept of consensus in a field because if more researchers provide sufficient detail for others to reproduce their results, then consensus on new knowledge can more often, and more rapidly, be established.

claims.claim_text: Reproducibility linked to consensus - enables more rapid establishment of consensus on new knowledge
claims.verbatim_quote: if more researchers provide sufficient detail for others to reproduce their results, then consensus on new knowledge can more often, and more rapidly, be established.

claims.claim_text: Reproducibility crisis is widespread across many fields
claims.verbatim_quote: These two factors have led to widespread concerns of a reproducibility crisis in many fields (Baker, 2016). Estimates of scientific reproducibility in several fields confirm the extent of this problem.

claims.claim_text: Computationally intensive research difficult to communicate within methods section constraints
claims.verbatim_quote: In part, this is because computationally intensive research is difficult to communicate within the constraints of the methods section of a traditional journal article — the reader also needs the computer code written by the original authors, not just the article text.

claims.claim_text: Strong incentives for malpractice from pressure to publish and competition for funds
claims.verbatim_quote: There is also the broader context of rising pressure to publish in prestigious journals and intense competition for funds that create strong incentives for malpractice in research (Edwards and Roy, 2017).

claims.claim_text: Evaluating reproducibility success has become distinctive meta-research activity in many fields
claims.verbatim_quote: These efforts confirm that the reproducibility of published research is widely recognized as a cornerstone of rigorous science, and work on evaluating how successful a research community is at generating reproducible results has become a distinctive and important meta-research activity in many fields.

claims.claim_text: Computational reproducibility of archaeological research is generally on low end of distribution compared to other fields
claims.verbatim_quote: By any measure, the computational reproducibility of archaeological research is generally on the low end of the distribution of values available from a variety of hard and soft sciences.

claims.claim_text: Reproducibility reviews provide opportunity to assess computational reproducibility in archaeology
claims.verbatim_quote: In 2024 the Journal of Archaeological Science introduced a new kind of peer review that has provided an opportunity to tackle this question about computational reproducibility in archaeology.

claims.claim_text: GitHub is problematic repository choice because lacks DOIs and long-term availability commitments
claims.verbatim_quote: GitHub, a commercial service owned by Microsoft, is a code hosting platform that is convenient for collaboration, is also popular among JAS authors, but is a problematic choice because does not offer DOIs or the same commitments to long-term availability as Zenodo.

claims.claim_text: Journal supplementary files are poor choice for long-term availability
claims.verbatim_quote: Some authors attached their code and data as journal article supplementary files, but this is a poor choice for long-term availability because these files are typically renamed and converted to different formats during the article production process, making it difficult or impossible for a reader to combine the code and data to reproduce the results.

claims.claim_text: Incomplete compendia mostly attributable to accidental carelessness
claims.verbatim_quote: In most cases this can be attributed to accidental carelessness, with the exception of two cases where data was unavailable due to licensing restrictions.

claims.claim_text: Data licensing restrictions caused unavailability in two cases
claims.verbatim_quote: with the exception of two cases where data was unavailable due to licensing restrictions.

claims.claim_text: Archaeology journals beginning to add AER positions (4 journals by 2024)
claims.verbatim_quote: In 2024, three archaeology journals, in addition to JAS, added AERs to their editorial communities

claims.claim_text: Empirical reproducibility has long been valued in field archaeology through site revisits
claims.verbatim_quote: Empirical reproducibility has long been valued in field archaeology. Throughout the history of archaeology, well-known sites have been repeatedly revisited to test old hypotheses with new evidence or methods, for example, Olduvai Gorge (Tanzania), Cahokia (USA), Çatalhöyük (Turkey), and Madjedbebe (Australia).

claims.claim_text: Experimental archaeologists value empirical reproducibility in studies like lithic use-wear
claims.verbatim_quote: Similarly among many experimental archaeologists, empirical reproducibility is a key concern, for example in lithic use-wear identification (Hayes et al., 2017) and the measurement of lithics (Pargeter et al., 2023).

claims.claim_text: Large digital datasets pushing archaeology into unexplored areas with questions about reproducibility meaning
claims.verbatim_quote: The increasing availability of large digital datasets is pushing archaeology into unexplored areas (Bevan, 2015), inviting questions about what reproducibility means for data intensive archaeological research.

claims.claim_text: Small set of simple tasks have high potential to increase reproducibility
claims.verbatim_quote: Despite the relatively small number of reproducibility reviews reported on here, there are patterns of common issues that point to a small set of simple tasks authors can do that have high potential to increase reproducibility.

claims.claim_text: Problem of incomplete materials can be tackled by simple folder structure and self-contained organisation
claims.verbatim_quote: The problem of incomplete materials can be tackled in several basic ways. First, authors should use a simple and logical folder structure to organise their code and data to be as self-contained as possible.

claims.claim_text: Authors should provide materials runnable as-is without manual modifications
claims.verbatim_quote: Authors should provide their materials organised such that a reader can successfully run all code as-is, without making any manual modifications (e.g. use relative rather than absolute file paths so that readers don't have to rename or move files around to make the code work)

claims.claim_text: Script files should have explicit run order in file names
claims.verbatim_quote: Script files should have the order in which they are to be run explicit in the file name, e.g. 001-load-data.R, 002-clean-data.R, 003-analyse-data.R.

claims.claim_text: README file should describe folders, files, and guide user to successful reproduction
claims.verbatim_quote: Second, authors should include in their compendium a README document that describes to readers the folders and files contained in the project (Abdill et al., 2024). The README file is typically the first file that a reader will look at in a compendium so it should include brief instructions to guide the user to a successful reproduction of the original results

claims.claim_text: Clear, direct connections between code and results should be documented
claims.verbatim_quote: Related to the basic documentation provided by the README, authors should document clear, direct and obvious connections between their code and the results they present in their paper

claims.claim_text: Dependencies are common cause of irreproducible results consistent with previous studies
claims.verbatim_quote: Our finding that dependencies are a common cause of irreproducible results is consistent with previous studies that have identified this as a widespread weakness in communicating computationally intensive research (Samuel and Mietchen, 2024; Trisovic et al., 2022).

claims.claim_text: Python dependency issues may be due to more package managers, environments, and deeper dependency chains
claims.verbatim_quote: One possible reason for this is that relative to R, Python uses more package managers, more environments, and deeper dependency chains with more complex inter-dependencies that change more rapidly

claims.claim_text: R community highly values code easy for others to reuse and has evolved effective dependency communication practices
claims.verbatim_quote: Another reason may be that there is a bigger and more established community of R users in archaeology (Batist and Roe, 2024; Schmidt and Marwick, 2020) that highly values code that is easy for others to reuse and has evolved practices to effectively communicate dependencies

claims.claim_text: Simplest dependency documentation: write names and version numbers in README
claims.verbatim_quote: The simplest way for archaeologists to improve here is to write the names and version numbers of the software and packages they used in their README file, as we see in Herskind and Riede (2024) and Monna et al. (2024).

claims.claim_text: For complex projects (5+ packages or ML), use dependency management tools
claims.verbatim_quote: For more complex research projects, i.e. those using five or more packages or machine learning algorithms, authors should use dependency management tools to keep track of the packages and version numbers needed to reproduce their results.

claims.claim_text: Dockerfile is leading best practice for managing dependencies in computationally intensive fields
claims.verbatim_quote: A more comprehensive solution, and the leading best practice for managing dependencies in many computationally intensive fields using Python in particular, is to include a Dockerfile in the compendium (Moreau et al., 2023).

claims.claim_text: Authors should re-run code more than once, ideally on different computer, before submission
claims.verbatim_quote: Finally, for analyses that are not highly time-consuming (which was over 90 % of the sample), authors should re-run their code more than once, and ideally not on the same computer (e.g. by another co-author of the paper), before submission to confirm everything works as expected

claims.claim_text: Complex analyses should use pipeline/workflow management tools
claims.verbatim_quote: Complex and time-consuming analyses should use pipeline or workflow management tools, e.g. GNU Make, Luigi, Snakemake, or Targets, to document the relationship of the files and folders in a machine-readable format and simplify running and re-running code by others

claims.claim_text: Literate programming tools enable research narrative and code to be woven together
claims.verbatim_quote: Another way some authors are accomplishing this is by using literate programming tools, such as Quarto and Jupyter notebooks (Allaire and Dervieux, 2024; Kluyver et al., 2016) that enable the research narrative and code for data analysis to be woven together in one document.

claims.claim_text: Qualitative archaeological research unquestionably counts as science because systematic, empirical, rigorous
claims.verbatim_quote: While these studies unquestionably count as science, because they are a systematic, empirical, and rigorous process of inquiry, should they be held to standards of reproducibility in the same way that computationally intensive research is?

claims.claim_text: Emerging consensus: for some but not all humanities studies, replication is possible and desirable, and will differ from field to field
claims.verbatim_quote: A consensus seems to be emerging that for some but not all, studies in the humanities, replication is both possible and desirable, and that replication studies will differ from field to field and might even differ among various studies within a specific field

consolidation_metadata.granularity_available: Original C065 text: 'replication studies will differ from field to field and might even differ among various studies within a specific field'
consolidation_metadata.rationale: C065 elaborated same point as C064 about field-by-field variation. Now combined as single integrated claim.

claims.claim_text: Key distinction for qualitative research: locus of evaluation is empirical rather than computational
claims.verbatim_quote: A key distinction here is that the locus of evaluation is empirical rather than computational, that is, concerned with appropriate reporting standards and documentation associated with physical evidence (e.g. artefacts and archives)

claims.claim_text: Qualitative/humanities research oriented towards replication rather than reproducibility
claims.verbatim_quote: A second important difference is that the debate about qualitative and humanities research is oriented towards replication (new data and/or new methods in an independent study to produce the same findings as original publication) rather than reproducibility (same data and same methods, e.g. computer code, to produce the same results as original publication)

claims.claim_text: Triangulation techniques support testing robustness of inferences against different evidence lines
claims.verbatim_quote: This orientation to replication emphasizes triangulation techniques that compare and integrate results coming from different traditions, locations, sources and methods, which in turn supports testing whether any given inference is robust in the face of different lines of evidence

claims.claim_text: Bibliometric analysis shows distinct disunity in archaeology increasing over time
claims.verbatim_quote: I have presented a bibliometric analysis on the status of archaeology as a science, showing distinct disunity that is increasing over time.

claims.claim_text: On average archaeologists behave as social scientists with some elements of harder sciences
claims.verbatim_quote: On average we generally behave as social scientists, with some elements in common with harder sciences.

claims.claim_text: Archaeology consists of multiple research programs with distinct, sometimes non-overlapping core assumptions
claims.verbatim_quote: These observations are consistent with Lakatos (1978)'s model of a research program as a central foundation of irrefutable core assumptions complemented by a set of hypotheses, models, and methods that are adjusted, modified, or replaced by day-to-day research. Archaeology consists of multiple programs like this, as indicated by the spread of journals across PC2 of Fig. 4, with distinct and sometimes non-overlapping sets of core assumptions.

claims.claim_text: Computational reproducibility essential for programs depending on quantitative methods to progress through increased consensus
claims.verbatim_quote: Among the programs that depend on quantitative methods to assess hypotheses and models, if they are to continue to progress through increased consensus through the accumulation of reliable facts and methods, it is essential for researchers to take computational reproducibility seriously.

claims.claim_text: Current state of quantitative archaeology comparable to secrecy of alchemy prior to chemistry
claims.verbatim_quote: However, the current state of quantitative archaeology, with most researchers not using open source code, is comparable to the secrecy of alchemy prior to the emergence of chemistry.

claims.claim_text: Abandoning secrecy in favour of transparency vital to avoid journals filled with unrepeatable methods
claims.verbatim_quote: Abandoning this habit of secrecy in favour of transparency and reproducibility is vital if we are to avoid a future where our journals are filled with pretty pictures depicting methods that the reader has no hope of repeating or adapting in their own work.

claims.claim_text: Computational reproducibility must be minimum requirement for evaluating integrity of quantitative results
claims.verbatim_quote: Computational reproducibility must be considered a minimum requirement for evaluating the integrity and usefulness of quantitative results.

claims.claim_text: Computational reproducibility is not panacea; should not be universal criterion for research quality
claims.verbatim_quote: Computational reproducibility is not a panacea; it should not be used as a universally accepted criterion for research quality (Leonelli, 2018).

claims.claim_text: Reproducible results can contain errors and fraud; no guarantee of code quality or appropriate statistics
claims.verbatim_quote: Results that are fully reproducible can contain errors and fraud. It is no guarantee of code quality, or that statistics have been used appropriately

claims.claim_text: Culture shift needed among senior archaeological scientists to value reproducibility in hiring and promotion
claims.verbatim_quote: This highlights the need for a culture shift among senior archaeological scientists to value reproducibility in hiring and promotion decision-making.

claims.claim_text: Professors must nurture culture of reanalysis and reproducibility in teaching
claims.verbatim_quote: Professors must contribute to this shift by nurturing a culture of reanalysis and reproducibility in their teaching, for example by using replication assignments and by training students in the most current best practices and tools for reproducible research, such as R and Python

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Bibliometric variables accurately capture 'hardness/softness' as a meaningful scientific construct that reflects consensus
trigger_text: empirical analysis of scholarly articles does support the hard-soft concept as a spectrum of variation in practice linked to differing degrees of consensus in a discipline

Following Fanelli and Glänzel (2013), I quantify the number of authors, length of article, relative title length, age of references, and diversity of references for a large sample of peer-reviewed journal articles
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper assumes bibliometric proxies (author count, article length, reference age/diversity) validly measure scientific consensus and hardness/softness without explicitly defending why these particular variables capture the theoretical construct. The link between observable bibliometrics and the latent concept of 'consensus' is assumed rather than demonstrated.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: 28% reproducibility success rate constitutes 'generally on the low end' compared to other fields based on unstated threshold
trigger_text: resulting in a 28 % success rate
the computational reproducibility of archaeological research is generally on the low end of the distribution of values available from a variety of hard and soft sciences
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper provides comparison data from other fields (26% Science, 15% statistics, 14-44% economics) but does not explicitly state what threshold distinguishes 'low end' from 'acceptable' or 'typical'. The characterisation of 28% as 'low end' requires an implicit judgment about where archaeological reproducibility should sit relative to other fields.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Single reviewer's attempt to run code constitutes adequate test of reproducibility quality
trigger_text: A reproducibility review examines the code and data used to generate the results presented in the paper, and attempts to run the authors' code to reproduce their results
conducted reproducibility reviews of submissions
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper assumes that one reviewer's attempt (the author) constitutes a valid test of reproducibility. Factors that could affect reproducibility success - reviewer expertise, available time, computational environment, interpretation of 'success' - are not discussed. The reproducibility review process itself is taken as adequate measurement without examining its validity or reliability.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Selection of journals by h-index produces sample representative of mainstream archaeological practice
trigger_text: I then filtered the results to keep only articles published in the top-ranking 25 journals according to their h-indices as reported by Clarivate's Journal Citation Indicator
To focus on journals of broad relevance to most archaeologists, and that are representative of substantial communities of practice
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Selecting journals by h-index (a citation-based metric) assumes that highly-cited journals represent 'broad relevance' and 'substantial communities'. This may systematically exclude innovative, regional, or non-Anglophone work that is less cited but still represents archaeological practice. The conflation of 'highly cited' with 'representative' is assumed without justification.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Author's dual role as AER and study author does not create conflict of interest affecting reported outcomes
trigger_text: In January 2024 I accepted the position of 'Associate Editor for Reproducibility' (AER) for JAS
we have completed 47 reproducibility reviews of 25 manuscripts submitted to JAS
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Author reports outcomes of reproducibility reviews he personally conducted without acknowledging potential bias from dual role. As both reviewer deciding what 'passes' and researcher reporting on success rates, there is potential for motivated reasoning in either direction (being more lenient to show success, or stricter to demonstrate need for reviews). This conflict is not acknowledged.

research_designs.design_text: Bibliometric approach to measure archaeology's position on hard-soft science spectrum using publication characteristics as indicators of disciplinary consensus
research_designs.verbatim_quote: To objectively quantify the diversity of modern archaeological practice across a scale of relative hardness or softness, as an evaluation of its status as a science, and the place of this journal in context of other archaeology journals, I take a bibliometric approach.

location.subsection: How to measure the hardness or softness of a science?

reasoning_approach.justification: Applies established Fanelli & Glänzel (2013) framework to test archaeology's position on pre-defined hard-soft spectrum

research_designs.design_text: Adoption of Fanelli & Glänzel (2013) five-variable bibliometric framework for measuring field hardness/softness
research_designs.verbatim_quote: This approach is based on Fanelli and Glänzel (2013), who examined the hardness and softness of 12 disciplines using scholarly publication parameters. Fanelli and Glänzel (2013) found a spectrum of statistically significant variation in bibliometric variables from the physical to the social sciences, with papers at the softer end of the spectrum tending to have fewer co-authors, use less substantive titles, have longer texts, cite older literature, and have a higher diversity of sources.

location.subsection: How to measure the hardness or softness of a science?

reasoning_approach.justification: Framework selection based on prior validation; five variables operationalise theoretical consensus concept

research_designs.design_text: Expanded temporal scope analysing 50 years of publications (1975-2025) rather than single-year snapshot to ensure robust representation across archaeological subfields
research_designs.verbatim_quote: While Fanelli and Glänzel (2013) analysed papers published in a single year (2012), I found only 303 papers for that same year, and 70 % of papers in the sample published after that date. To make efficient use of the available data and ensure robust representation from different areas of archaeology, including those with lower frequencies of journal article publication, I analysed 9697 papers published during 1975–2025.

location.subsection: How to measure the hardness or softness of a science?

reasoning_approach.justification: Design modification justified by data availability and representativeness goals

expected_information_missing: Justification for 1975 as start date not explicitly provided
No power analysis for sample size adequacy

research_designs.design_text: Reproducibility as additional measure of scientific status, linked to consensus-building capacity of a field
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Scientific reproducibility is a factor contributing to the hardness of a field. Specifically, reproducibility is linked to concept of consensus in a field because if more researchers provide sufficient detail for others to reproduce their results, then consensus on new knowledge can more often, and more rapidly, be established.

location.subsection: Reproducibility: a key measure of how scientific a field is

reasoning_approach.justification: Theoretical link between reproducibility and consensus (hard-soft framework) established before empirical investigation

research_designs.design_text: Journal selection design: focus on broad-relevance, high-impact archaeology journals representative of substantial communities of practice
research_designs.verbatim_quote: To focus on journals of broad relevance to most archaeologists, and that are representative of substantial communities of practice, I then filtered the results to keep only articles published in the top-ranking 25 journals according to their h-indices as reported by Clarivate's Journal Citation Indicator.

location.subsection: How to measure the hardness or softness of a science?

reasoning_approach.justification: Explicit rationale for journal selection criteria

expected_information_missing: Full list of 25 journals considered before filtering to 20

research_designs.design_text: Comparative positioning of archaeology relative to established hard and soft sciences as benchmark reference
trigger_text: What has been missing from these debates is a macroscopic observation of what the majority of archaeologists are actually doing, and an empirical comparison to a broad spectrum of relatively harder and softer disciplines.
Fig. 1 shows the distribution of bibliometric variables for archaeology in the context of data from other fields presented by Fanelli and Glänzel (2013).
research_designs.inference_reasoning: Paper systematically positions archaeology against physics, social sciences, and humanities throughout, but this comparative positioning goal is not stated as an explicit design objective in Methods. The Introduction mentions the gap (missing macroscopic observation) and Results deliver comparative analysis, but design rationale for choosing these comparators is assumed rather than documented.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Selection of Fanelli & Glänzel comparison disciplines not justified as design choice; assumes reader accepts these as appropriate benchmarks
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Moderate - comparison validity depends on comparability of included disciplines

research_designs.design_text: Issue taxonomy development for reproducibility review failures - categorical analysis of failure modes
trigger_text: Panels D and E of Fig. 5 summarise the common issues that resulted in irreproducible results. The most common issue was an incomplete compendium. This ranges from missing data files down to missing lines of code.
Unspecified or under-specified dependencies is another common issue that prevents code from running.

Other reasons why papers failed the reproducibility review is that the paths to data files were incorrectly specified (likely a result of the author reorganising their compendium after completing their analysis, or omitting data files from the materials submitted for review), and errors returned by functions, which have diverse causes.
research_designs.inference_reasoning: Results present a clear taxonomy of reproducibility failure types (incomplete compendium, dependencies, path errors, function errors) but the methodology for developing this taxonomy is not documented. No discussion of: whether categories were defined a priori or emerged from data, intercoder reliability for categorisation, or definitions/boundaries between categories.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Issue categorisation methodology absent - unclear if predefined taxonomy or emergent coding, no inter-coder reliability for single reviewer
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Moderate - affects interpretability of Figure 5 results; category boundaries may be subjective

methods.method_text: Five bibliometric variables analysis: number of authors, article length, relative title length, age of references (Price index), and diversity of references
methods.verbatim_quote: Following Fanelli and Glänzel (2013), I quantify the number of authors, length of article, relative title length, age of references, and diversity of references for a large sample of peer-reviewed journal articles.

location.subsection: How to measure the hardness or softness of a science?

methods.method_text: Web of Science database query for archaeology articles with systematic filtering
methods.verbatim_quote: This sample was collected from Clarivate's Web of Science database by first selecting the Web of Science category 'Archaeology' and the Document type 'article' (n = 28,871).

location.subsection: How to measure the hardness or softness of a science?

expected_information_missing: Web of Science subscription level not stated

methods.method_text: Journal filtering by h-index ranking with minimum article threshold
methods.verbatim_quote: To focus on journals of broad relevance to most archaeologists, and that are representative of substantial communities of practice, I then filtered the results to keep only articles published in the top-ranking 25 journals according to their h-indices as reported by Clarivate's Journal Citation Indicator. Finally, I excluded journals with less than 100 articles in the database, resulting in 20 journals.

location.subsection: How to measure the hardness or softness of a science?

expected_information_missing: Names of 5 journals excluded by 100-article threshold

methods.method_text: Bayesian Generalised Additive Models (GAMs) for temporal trend analysis of bibliometric variables
methods.verbatim_quote: Bayesian Generalized Additive Models were computed to fit the lines summarising the relationships between the variables and the time series.

location.subsection: Results (Figure 2 caption)

methods.method_text: Principal Components Analysis (PCA) for journal comparison on hard-soft spectrum
methods.verbatim_quote: The PCA results in Fig. 4 show that PC1 captures most of the variance in the metrics (71 %) and is a reasonable proxy for the hard-soft spectrum, with Journal of Cultural Heritage representing the hard extreme on the right and Journal of Archaeological Research representing the soft extreme on the left.

location.subsection: How do archaeology journals vary in hardness?

methods.method_text: Borda Count ranking algorithm for consensus journal ranking across five bibliometric variables
methods.verbatim_quote: Panel F shows a bar plot that is the single consensus ranking computed from all five variables, using the Borda Count ranking algorithm.

location.subsection: Results (Figure 3 caption)

methods.method_text: Reproducibility review methodology: code execution attempts and issue documentation for JAS submissions using R or Python
methods.verbatim_quote: In January 2024 I accepted the position of 'Associate Editor for Reproducibility' (AER) for JAS and conducted reproducibility reviews of submissions that mentioned programming languages such as R or Python in the methods sections, taking guidance from similar initiatives in other fields (e.g. Ivimey-Cook et al., 2023; Nüst and Eglen, 2021). A reproducibility review examines the code and data used to generate the results presented in the paper, and attempts to run the authors' code to reproduce their results.

location.subsection: How reproducible is archaeology? Investigating computational reproducibility

methods.method_text: Kendall's W (coefficient of concordance) for assessing agreement between bibliometric rankings
methods.verbatim_quote: Overall agreement between these bibliometric variables in ranking these journals on a hard-soft spectrum is moderate to strong, with a Kendall's coefficient of concordance (Wt) value of 0.64 (in a 0–1 range, where 1 is perfect agreement) and a p-value of 2.67 × 10−06.

location.subsection: How do archaeology journals vary in hardness?

methods.method_text: Issue categorisation methodology for reproducibility review failures
trigger_text: The most common issue was an incomplete compendium. This ranges from missing data files down to missing lines of code. In most cases this can be attributed to accidental carelessness, with the exception of two cases where data was unavailable due to licensing restrictions.
issues relating to dependencies are strongly associated with the use of Python
methods.inference_reasoning: Results discuss issue categories with apparent coding decisions (e.g., attributing cases to 'accidental carelessness', noting Python association), but no documentation of how issues were identified, categorised, or verified. Single reviewer with no reliability check.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No codebook, category definitions, or inter-rater reliability for issue categorisation
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Low-moderate - affects replicability of issue analysis but main findings (overall success rates) less affected

methods.method_text: Software/method type classification for reviewed papers (R vs Python, GMM vs AI/ML vs MCMC etc.)
trigger_text: The most commonly used software is R, followed by Python. Results generated with proprietary or closed-source software are out of scope for reproducibility reviews.

Several distinct types of analyses are well-represented in this sample, especially geometric morphometry, network statistics, and analyses using artificial intelligence or machine learning algorithms (this includes deep learning and neural networks).
methods.inference_reasoning: Figure 5 panels A and B present software and method type classifications, but classification methodology not described. How were 'AI/ML' vs 'MCMC' vs 'Frequentist' distinguished? Some papers may use multiple methods.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Method type classification scheme and decision rules not documented; potential overlap between categories unaddressed
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Low - descriptive rather than inferential use of classification

protocols.protocol_text: Sample construction protocol: Web of Science 'Archaeology' category, 'article' document type, top 25 journals by h-index, >100 articles threshold, resulting in 20 journals and 9,697 articles (1975-2025)
protocols.verbatim_quote: This sample was collected from Clarivate's Web of Science database by first selecting the Web of Science category 'Archaeology' and the Document type 'article' (n = 28,871). To focus on journals of broad relevance to most archaeologists, and that are representative of substantial communities of practice, I then filtered the results to keep only articles published in the top-ranking 25 journals according to their h-indices as reported by Clarivate's Journal Citation Indicator. Finally, I excluded journals with less than 100 articles in the database, resulting in 20 journals.

location.subsection: How to measure the hardness or softness of a science?

procedure_steps: Rank journals by h-index from Journal Citation Indicator

protocols.protocol_text: Price index calculation: proportion of cited works published within five years preceding the article
protocols.verbatim_quote: I calculated a recency of references index for each article (also known as the Price index), which is the proportion of all cited works that were published in the five years preceding the paper.

location.subsection: How to measure the hardness or softness of a science?

procedure_steps: For each article, identify publication year
Count references published within preceding 5 years

protocols.protocol_text: Relative title length calculation: article title word count divided by total page count
protocols.verbatim_quote: In order to generate results for comparison with Fanelli and Glänzel (2013) I follow their method of dividing the total word count of the article title by the total number of pages of the article to compute relative title length.

location.subsection: How to measure the hardness or softness of a science?

procedure_steps: Determine total page count of article
Divide title word count by page count

protocols.protocol_text: Bayesian GAM model specifications: ZOIB for recency, Gaussian for diversity/title length, Negative Binomial for author counts
protocols.verbatim_quote: For recency of references a Zero-One Inflated Beta distribution family was used with a logit link function. For diversity of references and relative title length (ln) the Gaussian family was used with the canonical identity link function. For the number of authors pages the Negative Binomial family was used with a standard log link function.

location.subsection: Results (Figure 2 caption)

procedure_steps: Recency of references: Zero-One Inflated Beta family, logit link
Diversity of references: Gaussian family, identity link
Relative title length (ln): Gaussian family, identity link
Number of authors: Negative Binomial family, log link

protocols.protocol_text: Research compendium publication: R code on Zenodo with MIT licence, data as CC-0, figures as CC-BY
protocols.verbatim_quote: The entire R code (R Core Team, 2024) used for all the analysis and visualizations contained in this paper is at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14897252 to enable re-use of materials and improve reproducibility and transparency (Marwick, 2017). All the figures, tables, and statistical test results presented here can be independently reproduced with the code and data in this compendium (Marwick et al., 2018). The R code is released under the MIT license, the data as CC-0, and figures as CC-BY, to enable maximum re-use.

location.subsection: How to measure the hardness or softness of a science?

procedure_steps: All R code deposited on Zenodo

protocols.protocol_text: Reproducibility review eligibility: papers mentioning R or Python in methods sections; guidance from Ivimey-Cook et al. (2023) and Nüst & Eglen (2021)
protocols.verbatim_quote: In January 2024 I accepted the position of 'Associate Editor for Reproducibility' (AER) for JAS and conducted reproducibility reviews of submissions that mentioned programming languages such as R or Python in the methods sections, taking guidance from similar initiatives in other fields (e.g. Ivimey-Cook et al., 2023; Nüst and Eglen, 2021).

location.subsection: How reproducible is archaeology? Investigating computational reproducibility

procedure_steps: Screen JAS submissions for R or Python mentions in methods
Review follows Ivimey-Cook et al. (2023) and Nüst & Eglen (2021) guidance

protocols.protocol_text: Success rate calculation variants: 7/25 reviewed (28%) or 7/97 total eligible (7%)
protocols.verbatim_quote: For comparison with reproducibility studies in other fields reported above, the seven fully reproducible papers should be divided by the 25 reviewed for reproducibility, resulting in a 28 % success rate. Expanding the denominator to include the total number of research articles published in JAS from May 2024 (when the first article to pass the reproducibility review, Herskind and Riede (2024), was published) to January 2025 (n = 97) offers another perspective. These 97 articles that could have been eligible for reproducibility review had the authors used an open source programming language (e.g. instead of commercial software such as Microsoft Excel or SPSS, etc.). Under this broader scope, the success rate is 7 %, a result also found in a study of 497 papers in 9 ecology journals (Kellner et al., 2025).

location.subsection: How reproducible is archaeology? Investigating computational reproducibility

procedure_steps: Broad scope: 7 fully reproducible / 97 total JAS articles = 7%

protocols.protocol_text: Reproducibility success criteria: distinction between 'fully reproducible on first attempt' vs 'required additional input from authors'
trigger_text: Seven of these eleven papers fully passed the reproducibility review, resulting in a success rate, by one measure, of 63 %. Four of the seven papers could be fully reproduced on my first attempt, the others required additional input from the authors.
protocols.inference_reasoning: Paper distinguishes between first-attempt success and success after author input, suggesting an implicit protocol for determining when to contact authors vs mark as failed. Threshold for 'additional input' not defined - could range from clarification to substantial code fixes.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No criteria for when reviewer sought author input vs marked failure; affects interpretability of 63% vs 28% rates
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Moderate - 'additional input' papers could be reframed as partial failures depending on definitions

trigger_text: The diversity of references is a similar indicator, with papers in harder fields having a higher concentration of more specific citations because more knowledge is taken for granted as core knowledge that does not need citing.
Conversely, softer fields have less knowledge taken for granted, a smaller core of facts that do not need citing, and thus a higher diversity of citations.
protocols.inference_reasoning: Paper discusses diversity of references as a key variable but doesn't specify the diversity measure used (Shannon index? Simpson? Unique journals cited? etc.). Fanelli & Glänzel (2013) reference implies their method was followed, but not stated explicitly.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Diversity metric not specified; replication requires consulting Fanelli & Glänzel (2013) or code
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Low - code is available for verification

consolidations_performed.rationale: Identical support pattern (all support only C011), sequential sample construction steps
Identical support pattern (all support only C026), components of single PCA analysis
C065 elaborated same point about field-by-field variation in replication

pass_2_summary.consolidation_justification: Lower consolidation rate (2.6%) appropriate for meta-analysis paper with discrete data points. Evidence items serve distinct comparative analytical roles (different field reproducibility rates). Methodological recommendations are specific actionable items warranting separate assessment. Pass 1 extraction was already well-calibrated with minimal redundancy.

extraction_notes.id_renumbering_note: Evidence IDs E004-E050 after consolidation (original E005-E006 absorbed into E004; E019-E021 into E019). Original Pass 1 evidence items E004-E052 now E004-E050 with some gaps. Claim ID C065 removed (absorbed into C064).
known_uncertainties: Author ORCID not visible in paper text; may be present in published version metadata
Specific renv.lock or environment specification assumed present in Zenodo compendium but not verified
Some methodological claims (C049-C060) are recommendations rather than findings - classified as methodological_argument
Paper type classified as methodological/meta-analysis - hybrid of bibliometric empirical study and reproducibility review analysis

paper_characteristics.structure: Standard journal article (Abstract, Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion, Conclusion)
paper_characteristics.methodology_type: Meta-analysis combining bibliometric study and systematic review of reproducibility reviews
primary_data_sources: Web of Science database (9,697 articles from 20 archaeology journals, 1975-2025)
JAS reproducibility reviews (47 reviews of 25 manuscripts, May 2024-January 2025)

pass_3_summary.notes: Liberal explicit RDMAP extraction from methodological/meta-analysis paper. Dual study design: (1) bibliometric analysis using Fanelli & Glänzel framework, (2) reproducibility review analysis. Strong method documentation with explicit statistical procedures.

actions: Reviewed 7 research designs for consolidation - none consolidated (distinct strategic decisions)
Reviewed 10 methods for consolidation - none consolidated (distinct analytical approaches)
Reviewed 9 protocols for consolidation - none consolidated (distinct procedures)
pass_5_summary.notes: Paper has clear methodology - most RDMAP items explicit. Implicit items capture: (1) comparative benchmark selection rationale, (2) issue taxonomy methodology, (3) success criteria distinctions, (4) reference diversity measurement procedure.

automated_checks.bidirectional_validator: PASS (41 auto-corrections applied, 2 conflicts resolved manually)

hierarchy_validation.orphan_note: P005 (compendium publication) legitimately standalone - documentation protocol

minor_issues: P005 has no implements_methods link - acceptable as standalone documentation protocol
